reviewText:
--REVIEW IN PROGRESS--

For the record, I've already played through this game multiple times (smartphone and PS Vita). This version seems to be a direct port of the game from the smartphone app. I'm putting my review as recommended based on my previous experience, however, as I play this version I will update the review accordingly.

First off, I really love this game. I like the characters, and each route feels interesting, as well as the setting this takes place in. Finding out the reasons or motivations for characters to why they're in Kikuya is an interesting mystery, though I admit some scenarios are just frustrating. Certainly not for everybody, as things can get very intimate (there's, um, R18+ stuff described), but it's something that I think is enjoyable to some. It's probably D3Publisher's best otome game, or at least, it's most popular if it's getting a Steam release. That said, this version has a lot of flaws.

Being that this is a direct port, all the routes of all the guys available in the smartphone version so far are here. I played the entirety of the prologue, and for the most part there were few changes in the text, if at all. What I noticed is that they took out character animations, and they improved the GUI for players in the main game. However, it still retains a very smartphone" feel
date: and inputs often feel sluggish. Furthermore
recommended: the way they ported it gives you no options to change your resolution. You're given a measly "Screen change" to go to fullscreen mode
hoursPlayed: but if you do that the ENTIRE GAME becomes blurry and pixelated. Save slots are limited
voteText: something I hated about the original as well
helpfulPercent: but route exploration is not that difficult.\n\nThe font is strange and there seem to be white artifacts floating around in it. They also didn't clean it up as much as I would have hoped for
votesHelpful: so many lines will seem very awkward. If I recall correctly
votesTotal: Hayabusa's routes have much cleaner and better translated dialogue.\n\nThey used the opening from the PS Vita version
commentsCount: which makes me wonder why they didn't just port that version and included Hayabusa. The PS Vita versions (Otoko Yukaku) is superior to the smartphone version and this version combined. That version has improved art (fixing awkward character portraits)
column18: an extra character (Keiji Ito) and voice acting from famous Japanese seiyuus. Furthermore
column19: it has extra endings and new scenarios and CGs. To top it off
column20: the main routes of the main five guys (Takao

because this version is inferior to the PS Vita one.

I was also just told the event CGs from the Vita version are in this one. I'll have to see them in the routes.

I'm hoping things get cleaned up

reviewText: Its not bad for what it is. I purchased it on sale and was happy to do so but after learning that there is a fully voiced and more dynamic PS Vita version, I am really glad I didn't pay full price. This is essentially a direct port from the mobile platform and while I would truly LOVE more of the mobile otomes to come to Steam, I would really prefer they were the voiced or PS versions for the higher prices.\n\nI don't wish to discourage the publishers but the voice acting makes these like 1000x better.

reviewText:
I read fast, it took me 3 hours to complete Takao’s route and all the additional content for him. I was a little bummed at first about the lack of voice acting, but it does allow me to go faster when I’m just reading : )

I am looking forward to playing the other routes. I’ve played a number of Voltage titles on my phone and tablet, and I hope to see more app games ported to Steam. I really prefer PC gaming when possible (with achievements, yay!)

Pros
Beautiful art work
Intimate scenes – this otome goes beyond kissing :O
A unique plot (it’s a little ridiculous, but that’s okay :)

Cons
Awkward translations
Typos
Cost – While full price is apparently cheaper than buying all the routes on mobile, I wouldn’t recommend paying $29.99 for this (if you have that much to spend go get Amnesia Memories or Nameless - better quality and more content for the price). I feel the price would be fairer at $9.99 ($14.99 tops), especially given the poor quality of the translations. Try to wait for a sale to buy this.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game. Even though the premise is the same, all character have routes that feel different and show the situation from a slighly different angle. Everyone has very different, as i call it, Drama Plot, and sometimes it can be really, really surprising. A couple of routes totally went the way i didn't expect and that was really cool. My favourite is Iroha, i think, but i honestly liked them all a lot.
But man. The art. It's so stunning and wonderful, a huge part of my gameplay was staring at cgs or sprites in pure awe. As a fellow artist, i felt that artworks in this game were totally my art goals. I'd recommend the game for that alone, and yet it has a very well done story with it. Amazing!
Music isn't really outstanding, although there's one track (which i fondly call Takao's Theme, since it plays for the first time when he shows up) that i love wholeheartedly. What's good it's that common music doesn't get annoying even after playing all the routes.
I liked how gentle and not very vulgar nsfw scenes were. As for someone who doesn't really enjoy nsfw things, it was a huge relief, since i was afraid i'd just have to skip some scenes while sighing annoyed.
What might be not everyone's cup of tea is that the game is ultimately sweet, happy, and cute. It tries really hard to show some drama and action, but the sugar and love overwhelm everything. It is not essentialy a bad thing, and is perfectly enjoyable, just be aware that it's that kind of game where love always wins and is the most important. After money.
As for downsides, it's kinda sad not everything from the vita port of the game was brought to steam. I also felt sad that there's no equal amount of side stories per character. It kinda feels like something is lacking, but i have no idea whether original japanese game has more stories. If it does, i hope they will be implemented eventually.
As the game is now, i don't think i can recommend it for the full price. But when it's discounted, go for it. I spent some quality time playing this game.

Oh yeah, and heroine's mother is the best character in the game. Just sayin'.

reviewText:
Looking at the steam port, there are features lacking that I would like to see added: voices, the 7th love interest, the animated sprites.

The mobile version is pay per route/story which costs FAR more than the asking price on steam for the full game.

Price breakdown of the mobile version:Main Story - $3.99 x 7 (Iroha's sequel is not purchasable until you buy his first main story) = $27.93
Sequel Story (not purchasable until you buy the main story) - $0.99-1.99 (I'm assuming based on length)
Date Story (not purchasable until you buy the main story) - $0.99-1.99 (I'm assuming based on length)
Sub stories $0.99 each x 16 = $15.84If I assume the sequel and date stories are $0.99, the price for 1 route = $5.97 x 7 = $41.79

Therefore I think the steam version is the better one to buy if you want to experience the full game. The vita version is not available in English, but is the only version with voices.

+ Art is very nice. I quite like the painterly, soft colors with sketchy lineart. Sometimes the MC has eyes, sometimes she's drawn in an angle that purposefully hides them.
+ There are 2 endings for each guy, super happy ending and happy ending. Both endings are HAPPY in the full sense of the word, which I'm A-OK with. I've been playing a lot of games with bad/unfulfilling endings so these felt refreshing to me.
+ There is bonus content. You can unlock a few short stories as well as short epilogues.
+/- Romance is the main focus of the plot (forbidden love). Lightly to moderately smutty, ranging from descriptions of kissing and touching to metaphorical descriptions of sex. Brief scenes of softcore porn is the most accurate way to describe it.
+/- Quite a few grammar errors here and there on each route. This did not bother me much as I play a lot of mobile otome games where the translation is almost always poorly done.
+/- The story explores the world it set up, but does not focus on the truly dark themes it presents. Forbidden romance is the main theme of D3 Publishers's/Dogenzaka Lab's otome game titles. I enjoyed reading the stories for the most part.
- The MC is super naive and reckless. I should be tolerant of this, since these traits are so common for otome protagonists, but it doesn't stop it from being infuriating at times.
- BGM is monotonous, I found myself muting it after 2 playthroughs.
- Unvoiced. There is a voiced Vita version that also has a 7th guy, not to mention the mobile version has sprite animations that were removed from this port as well.
- Chapters end abruptly, which makes them feel short. The only exception is Iroha's sequel, which has less chapters, but are lengthy and are divided appropriately. The extra stories are also short.
- The choices don't really seem to matter, as you can easily achieve the super happy ending with less than 50% likeability (except Hayabusa and Iroha's sequel route).

I would recommend this because the steam version has all of the story content available for a reasonable price (versus the mobile version). I prefer stories that have a lot of romance (I'm pretty tolerant with sleazy, cheesy romances), so this game definitely fills that spot for me.

The steam version has gone on sale (about twice now) for about $10 which is a must buy price if you ask me. I bought the game on release which was $18 and I felt it was worth the value.

reviewText:
Installed the android version a few days before this popped up. I miss the animations on the phone a little as they were removed but it doesn't lose much. The art work is beautiful, the stories are really good so far.
On reflection each story on the android version is £2-3. There's 6 characters witha main story, a sequal and a date all in that price range each. Iroha has a 2nd season and there's a bunch of side stories as well. Whether you buy this game at £14 on offer or £23 at full price you are getting a bargain as the android price would come to above £40 easily. I think more visual novels should do this.
There are a fare few spelling errors but considerably less than if you read Metro" news articles so that's something.

reviewText:
When I bought this game, I hadn't expected it to have SO much content. I have a little over eight hours in and there's still much more for me to enjoy.

When your mother asks you to run an errand for her, you end up in the Yoshiwara pleasure district, where the men of the island you live on offer their bodies to women in exchange for money. At one of the more famous brothels, they mistake you for the daughter of a wealthy merchant, and invite you to pick out one of their courtesans for the night. And purely by accident, you happen to have a lot of money on you; enough to buy a dreamy night of pleasure...

Depending on who you pick for the night, the story diverges from there as you explore your romance with this beautiful courtesan. There are six guys to choose from, all with different and distinct personalities, and playing their route will give you background information on them. They all have dreams they wish to achieve, despite their situation, and maybe you can help them with that...

The Good+ Lots and lots of content! Sequel stories, date scenes, etc
+ Many romance options to choose from, not all with stereotype personalities
+ Intimate, steamy scenes; definitely 18+ (though the art is not explicit)
+ All characters get a bit of depth
+ Gorgeous artwork
+ Almost impossible to get a bad ending with the man of your choice

The Bad- Horrendous editing for the English version, including but not limited to: homophones, bad translations, messed-up character names, weird punctuation, typos, etc.
- Only two or maybe three background songs
- Rushed art here and there
- A weird focus on the main protagonist being a pure & innocent virgin
- The protagonist in general is very passive and weepy
- Some creepy sexual behaviour, but not in all routes
- If you put the game on full-screen, it becomes terribly pixelated

In the end, I would recommend this game if you're into visual novel/otome/romance games but ONLY if you wouldn't be bothered by the terrible editing. For me, that's the worst part of the game. Unlike many of the other reviewers here, I never played other versions of this game but the PC version, so I was not bothered by the lack of animation in the character art, for example.

At its core, this game is a romantic & steamy adventure. All the romance options get some manner of depth when you play through their route, and not all of them turn out to be the stereotypical man you had expected them to be. Of course, I fell head over heels for the stoic intellectual, Kagura, though the manager of the store (Iroha) also has one heck of a story.

Just... maybe don't buy this game at full price. Content-wise, it might be worth it, but in terms of editing for the English version and lack of animated character art & voice acting, it's not. Oh well. I did end up buying it at full price myself anyway because I was on a ridiculous romance game rampage.

reviewText:

✔ The opening song for the game and graphics is really good!
✔ Very nice graphics for most scenes
✔ soothing music to match the different scenarios
✔ Really good looking guys with different personalities to suit different girls
✔ A LOT of heart - cringing moments (I cried quite a few times while playing this game
✔ A lot of M18 scenes *cough cough* if you know what I mean. (Don't act like you don't like it :3)
✔ Beautiful CGs of the men of yoshiwara (A MUST FOR ALL GOOD OTOME GAME)

✘ Very little development plot between the girl and choosen man (I raged when I was playing this game as the guy would SUDDENLY fall in love with you one way or another, without you trying.)
✘ Music will keep re-looping that you might get annoyed if you are stuck at the same scene for a while
✘ Your friends might think you are crazy when you start to scream about how much the guy cares about you. (Do NOT play it when your friends are around, esp male friends (I am being labelled as hentai for screaming so many times.))

If you like to get guys to like you easily, you must try this game.
If you like to get guys the hard way, please turn to real life, you will be able to find it difficult to get the man of your dream. Not impossible but just difficult.
Have fun with the game!

reviewText: I'm giving this a positive review because it's a sweet, inoffensive visual novel that is a reasonable way to pass time and it at no point made me angry. It's not high art by any means (and there could have been an interesting setting there that is glossed over and generally unexplored), and the translation isn't great, but the art is pretty. The routes are all very self-contained, and there's no way not to get a guy you're chasing once you're on one; no sudden bad endings or game overs. The guys are also fairly interchangeable, and most of the focus on each route is on the protagonist's personal growth, rather than on them.\n\nSo, if you like visual novels, you could do way worse than this, just wait until it's on sale.

I've played though all of the mobile game and I really enjoyed it. Writting is what you suspect out of a game like this. reviewText:
I enjoyed this game.

I'm going to review on a general level and avoid huge spoilers here.

The first thing that stood out to me was the artwork. It's what drew me to this game in the first place. I think it's very nice and I like the style.  I have no complaints about the art itself, but it's more about me pointing out inconsistencies: (1) Regarding the CG's, sometimes the heroine's eyes would show, and in others they don't. I know that it's a thing in visual novels, but usually games would have already decided with showing the main character's eyes most of the time or not in CG's. (2) The clothes of the person the heroine is talking to would change from time to time, but the dialogue makes no note of him changing clothes. Aside from that, the art seems soft, much like the heroine's personality.

Regarding the story, some routes were more interesting than others. Some routes showed more character development and relationship progression than others. It was a bit unrealistic to fall in love after a couple of days, but I did enjoy the stories for what they were. Personally, my favorite route was when I pursued a certain manager. It's nice that the game included a second story for him. On the other hand, the heroine's childhood friend does not appear in other routes, does not have any substories, and is not mentioned in any other route. I happen to like the childhood friend trope, so I was a bit disappointed with that. There were also some spelling errors (homophones) and awkward use of some words throughout the game. Like the use of comfit" in the game... I think it was referring to konpeito? Not a big deal
date: but the dialogue was a bit confusing at times.\n\nAnyway
recommended: by the time I finished all the stories and the routes
hoursPlayed: I still wanted to read more. I don't regret the purchase
voteText: despite the things I pointed out. I fully enjoyed it and I liked all the characters."

reviewText: If you are a fan of otome games and wish there were more in English this is one that should be on your list.  The translation into English is easy to understand and there haven't been any moments where I felt 'lost in translation'. The story/subject matter is fairly mature but without moving into eroge(18+).  The stories were more compelling than I expected and fairly diverse. The character art is beautiful and reminds me of the Starry Sky series. The backgrounds, game design, is all pretty standard for any kind of dating sim, but I gotta admit I love the colors chosen. Worth picking up to support otome games in English!!!

reviewText:

update needed.
Only problem I have is no voices ;-;\n\nother than that lovely game !

A very solid experience!
The romanceable characters have distinct personalities and motives. The art is usually quite beautiful, although there are some wonky sprites and CGs, but nothing major, and the MC has eyes! Her personality is way better than I expected. Sure, she's an otoge MC, but the stereotypical elements of her personality are plot-related and she can actually be assertive. I fond the soundtrack quite pretty, although I suspect there are only 3 songs remixed. It's a port from mobile, so it's no deal breaker.
The chapter format and UI and the narrative itself were clearly made with smartphones in mind. The narrative can't be super deep, but I found it engaging and the characters were diverse enough to make me enjoy each route. Sequels, Date Scenarios and Sub Scenarios are included as well with a handful of CGs from the Vita version. I'm a bit bummed that there are no voices nor the E-mote animations, but I can live without. The textboxes are prettier in this version, by the way.
As a Voltage fan with a wallet freshly emptied by their sale I can't but recommend this game. There are actual sexy scenes in this game! The MC enjoys her time. You go, girl.
This game also prompted me to look for the other Forbidden Romance games on the Play Store. Hope they'll port those too, I wouldn't mind paying full price for everything. I got Yoshiwara in the Steam Holiday Sale and I feel bad because I want to give more money to this company... I also got the mobile version and I'll gladly purchase extra stories and whatnot ;)
My personal route preference from best to still enjoyable: Kagerou > Tokiwa > Kagura > Takao > Iroha > Hayabusa

I've never left a review for a game on here (that I can remember), but after playing through every route the steam version has to offer I feel compelled to. This game was a happy accident, and is now one of my favorite otome games ever. If you enjoy visual novels and are willing to read something more mature then this game will definitely be the better buy than the mobile version.

The short version:

Pros
-Great storylines per route. They all tend to interact with each other well without being too repetitive.
-Great characters. I honestly don't dislike any of the cast. Yet they're each unique.
-Music is great. I wish I just had the soundtrack.
-Artwork is beautiful (even if some expressions can get a tad wonky)
-In terms of content, you actually get a lot in this package. Keep in mind on mobile platforms each route costs roughly $3.00, plus different price tags for most of the other bonus content.
-Fun and cheesy writing (also a con XD )
-The backdrop of the story is actually really friggin' dark when you think about it.
-Promotes a proactive heroine. The men are trapped in Kikuya and can't see you. If you want the man, YOU have to chase after them.
-Doesn't shame sexuality and actually promotes it.
-Little details from character designs, to the rules of how service in Kikuya takes place, are decently accurate mirrors of Oiran life back during the Edo period (with some creative liberties, of course).

Cons
-No voiceovers, which is a CRYING SHAME. This game was originally made for the PSP or PS Vita which sported voice acting from a top-notch cast, including the giant known as Kosuke Toriumi. Those who also have a basic knowledge of Japanese will miss out on furthur understanding since we have to rely only on the translated text.
-Despite this being a port of the mobile version, we don't get the sprite animations the movile versions have. So basically we got cheated in terms of ports.
-Cheesy writing in some of the scenes. Also some relatively odd choices in editing.
-Choices don't really change the actual story. You might get a different reaction but the plot doesn't really diverge.
-PSVita version has another character that we don't: Keiji.
-Price, despite the content you get with it, isn't very competitive. I bought this on sale for $19.99 or something like that, and I felt that price was much more fair. You can buy the infamous Hakuouki and Sweet Fuse for much cheaper than this and both games offer easily twice the content. Unless you have extra money hanging around I'd wait for a sale.

The More Detailed version

The Men of Yoshiwara immediately caught my attention because of the unique premise. During the Edo period of Japan (the period of isolation before the Meiji restoration), there were segregated pleasure quarters in designated Flower Towns" where prostitution was legalized with very strict rules. Yoshiwara was one of those towns. Here Oiran (NOT Geisha. There are differences)
date: or courtesans as the game calls them entertain clients with similar skill sets to Geisha but also sell their bodies for a night of pleasure and companionship. Basically ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a heart of gold story.\n\nUsually in stories revolving around the Floating World the women are the center piece
recommended: but this game turns the idea on its head by putting men in the role of the Oiran. In this game's case it also comes with a bit of a tragic story: men are apparently very rarely born. As such
hoursPlayed: all men born on your island are automatically sold to the pleasure district in order to help women have babies. Yeah...these guys are basically breeding tools. Hence my point about a dark backdrop.\n\nThis also shows us male characters in a more vulnerable light. Usually in otome games men are much more...powerful. More overwhelming. After all they're the stars so they should stand out. But here they're Oiran
voteText: and it's illegal for them to freely chase the heroine. So we get to see males still exhibit their masculinity but also be vulnerable. Some of their stories are actually pretty heartbreaking. You still get the scenes where they take the lead and teach the heroine about "love" and dominate
helpfulPercent:
but for the most part this vulnerability of them being trapped and exploring typically "feminine" tropes is a side to these characters we don't see often. And it's a very enjoyable change of pace!

That being said every game has its hang ups. Certain portions of the game do read like a cheesy (badly written) romance novel. Which can make this HYSTERICAL to play with friends reading aloud. However sometimes it does drive you out of the immersion (those who played Iroha's route will know what I mean: "His whitefish fingers." ...what? Or even "I accepted his wedge." Wedge? Really? ). On top of this the player's choices really don't change how the story plays out much. You only gain points towards one of two possible outcomes.I'm actually a little bumed there's no bad ending possibility because in this scenario there's PLENTY abound that could have happened.

That said
votesHelpful: the story's unique and the characters are just downright adorable. Iroha and Kagerou won me over
votesTotal: but my heart ached for each guy. The Heroine is also surprisingly progressive! She's usually the one who makes the first step in initiating actions in the storyline. It's one of the few games that made me want to play through every possible outcome.\n\nHuge thank you to the developers for localizing the game in English! And thank you for giving us a complete package on Steam. I HATE the nickel and dime method mobile otome games enforce. Definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun otome game to get lost in. Just beware: it's rated M for a reason ;D"

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: The Men of Yoshiwara: Kikuya
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Dogenzaka Lab
Publisher: Dogenzaka Lab
Release Date: 15 Oct, 2015

OverviewThe Men of Yoshiwara: Kikuya is a fun little novelist styled type of game. The characters seem to be fairly interesting and the setting of the game fits in with the characters and where they are in the game. This game is definatly not everyones cup of tea, some parts of the game are somewhat.... intimate with 18+ stuff that isn't really said at all in the game so just be aware of that. This game is also a port from phones, with a few changes in the text, but they took the animtations out of the characters for some reason I am unsure about though.

Game PlayThis game is a novel, romance game. I believe that it was orignally made for phones, and therefore this game is a port, although having a look at the phone version, it seemed that they took out the animations for the characters for some bizarre reason. The game itself is fun if you are the sor tof person who likes to play there romance, novelist games for hours on end. For me personally I got bored of the game after doing the first route which took me about 2 hours to do. It seems that each character has it's own route, with a regular and true ending to them both. Upon doing some research on this game, there is a character that comes with two routes which increases the replay value of the game slightly. There are also a fair amount of achievements implimented into the game, and a few trading cards to be idled for as well. However, there are a few problems that I have with this game. I am going to assume that this game was orginally made for Japanese, that takes me to my next point about the translation of the game. Of course, you can't always translate things 100% correctly, (even if you do use Google translator) but there are some typos here and there while I was playing the game. Also some of the words where getting cut off at the end so it made it rather difficult to read.
Score (Out of 10): 5 - This game seems to have a lot of gameplay, if you are into this kind of genre then you will get the maximum game play out of it.

Graphics/Art StyleDespite some of the negativity overwhelming the positive on the Game Play section of this review, the art style for this game kind of makes up for it. It seems that the developers really worked hard to get this really nice art style to fit with the type of game they where creating. The small details like the lighting and shading of the game makes it really look vibrant and nice. The shine in the characters hair really does look rather nice. Although sometimes the characters positioning did look a little weird, with their hands at awkward angles that didn't really look natural or comfortable to be in that position.
Score (Out of 10): 9 - the art style looks really nice, really sets the atmosphere for this game. However there are a few weird hand postures that are at awkward angles.

Sound & MusicI myself kind of liked the music for the small proportion that I was playing the game for. However, the music track was rather short and it was continously looping itself. I found myself getting rather annoyed at the same soundtrack over and over again so I turned off the music itself. If they could maybe add some more music to the game, or make the music last longer then I might've played more of the game itself.
Score (Out of 10): 7 - the music fitted the atmosphere, but it got rather repetitive and boring. Possibly add more music to the game or make the music last longer.

For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Sometimes You Playing curator group here.

reviewText:
I feel like I shouldn't be judged for playing this game.
The art is good and the CG images are nice but the plot felt like a failure.
It didn't have much depth to it, the answers were rather apparent and the text had grammatical and spelling mistakes.
The story was overall rather predictable, cheesy and, honestly, so horrible that it was actually funny to play through this.
Provided that I'm only less than halway through, but I don't imagine the plot or gameplay getting any better later on.

Maybe I'm getting too old for otome games. This was targetted for an audience of 18+ though..
All in all, don't buy an otome game without reading the summary first. The art isn't always the only thing to look at while picking your game of choice.

reviewText:
Just bought the game and I really don't regret it. I'm usually not a big fan of visual novels but I saw all these guys at the screenshot and wanted to give it a try.
I'm really amazed from all the diffrent characters and the story lines. It's really awesome. The artworks are really great. I already played teh whole Tokiwa storyline and at the moment I'm in the middle of the Kagura storyline. I already loved the storyline of Tokiwa really much but to me it got beaten by Kagura. Love it~ <3

I really can recommend this game. It was worth every cent I paid =3

The game is hard to follow at times because of the translation difficulties, and the lack of voice acting leaves something to be desired.  Even with those two marks against it The Men of Yoshiwara: Kikuya is a very enjoyable VN.

The art is just STUNNING, with vibrant colors, fun character designs, and beautifully full backdrops.   Almost all of the expressions are spot on, and do a good job of helping a reader connect with the character, instead of wondering how his hand bends like that.

I haven't disliked any of the plots, which is a surprise, as normally there is that one in every game that you just want to... grrrrrr.  Normally this is the shy man-child charicter for me, or the self-important business man.  Both of those archetypes are absent however, and the features they possess are well distributed among the less stereotypical choices.

While not perfect by any measure if you are looking for a fun way to waste a few weeks in the afternoon, you could do much MUCH worse; tryst me, I have.

I really enjoy this game as well as the other otome games made from the same group. I highly recommend this to all those otome game fans out there.

This game is really for all you Otome Visual Novel lovers! <3 It has everything that you want in here! With a variety of various men! They even have sequels to their stories, date scenarios for the guys, even a second season story for one of the guys. One of the plots even made me tear up a little  T T. Serously, check this game out if your a fan of otome visual novels. I write this while its on sale for 18 bucks and trust me THAT PRICE is not bad at all! For all the scenarios to pay for them indivdually like you would, plus tax, would be over 35 bucks! Though this game does not include voices, I still had a blast reading it and getting sucked into the story. <( ^ _ ^ )>

I've already played the mobile version except Hayabusa and some of the side stories, and this being a direct port, I already know what to expect story-wise.

I've been a big fan ever since its first release on iOS. The character art is great, the music is decent (it's pretty common for mobile otome not to have sounds) and the story is enjoyable.

My complaints with this version is that almost every word has a full stop. Like. What. Happened.?!
Also, when in fullscreen, the resolution drops A LOT! Suddenly everything goes into .jpeg mode :/ Everything's blurry and jaggy and the text is hard to read as well.
I hope this gets fixed in the future.

I'd still recommend this for those who want something different *and also because I'm a fangirl*(are there any other otome that are about literal man♥♥♥♥♥s?)

I'm trying to get into this game, but I'm having a hard time. The background is a constant loop of stereotypical classical Japanese music that doesn't always match the tone of the scene appropriately. The artwork is nice, but not the best (I can't get over how cross-eyed Kagura looks 95% of the time). I've played through Takao and Kagura's stories so far, and I'm not terribly impressed. The characters have a little depth, but nowhere near that of other comparable otome games I've played. The main story lines are pretty short, too.\n\nFor a $30 pricetag, play Nameless or Amnesia to get the full experience. This game is fun, but there are better ones out there. Still worth a look, though.

This may not be the number one otome game on Steam (I would give that title to Amnesia: Memories for now), but it is worth your time and money and definitely makes me feel good to play!  If you have ever played any mobile otome games, you know what you are in for.  You choose your guy right from the start, there are distinct chapters and side stories, and the story is VERY ADDICTIVE!  Unlike mobile offerings, however, you pay one price to own the game and have everything right from the start.  No distracting microtransactions, in-app purchases, energy, etc.  The game is perfect to play in very small bursts, but if I had more time I could definitely see myself enjoying just going through a whole route all at once!  I am always eager to find out what happens next.\n\nThe short prologue followed by a screen where you choose your guy" reeks of a mobile game money-making setup

I just finished the game so here is my short review.

I really loved the game a lot despite typos showing here and there playing the game.

The artwork and the music was very lovely. Though not a lot of tracks would play in the game. I still liked the tracks that.
would play.

As you can tell by the age requirement that the game will have adult writing. As someone mentioned in their review the game goes beyond kissing;) But at least the pictures shown are not inapropiate but very beautiful. I'm pretty sure if some pictures were inapropriate those pictures would of gotten censored on steam anyways.

In my opinion my favorite route I played was Iroha's route. Second pick is tough so I cant say LOL.

Honestly there where only a few things that bugged me.

1-I really wish Hayabusa was included in the game more. For some reason you only see him in his route and he has the least pictures to unlock:( If Hayabusa had more content I would of rated him my second favorite route to play.

2-I found out from reading that The Men Of Yoshiwara has a PSVita version. This is important because this is not the Vita version. The Vita version has voice acting and an extra charcter to play. So for this reason I would only buy this on a sale and not the $29.99. I bought this on the $17.99. Games like these cost a bit as you have to pay to play this one. At least for $17.99 it's so much worth this version that steam has put out at least. But if they brought the Vita version I would of gladly pay the $29.99. Let's be honest voice acting escpecially in a VN makes the VN a hundred times better.

So all in all if you like VN, not bothered by typos, despite the fact that there is a Vita version and not bothered by this fact I would get The Men Of Yoshiwara. I would buy only on discount though.

I almost didn't get the game due to the fact that I read that there was a Vita version but still glad I took a chance and got this nice VN.

So to leave off have a fun time playing The Men Of Yoshiwara;)
Nice game
AN AMAZING OTOME GAME!!! :D i love the story and the characters of this game the soundtrack is quite amazing!

Thoughts (after playing through four routes):

If you're to buy this game, don't expect an intricate plot or more depth and development to the romances like the romances found originally on console/PC. This PC version (and the Vita version) was based off the original otome game on IOS and Android which like many mobile otome games, were designed for playing during the trips to school/work on public transport - so it was made to be brief. Despite this, I still enjoyed playing the routes, they were a lighthearted from other heartbreaking/heartwrenching otome games I have played and it was interesting seeing the different motivations and reasons for being in Kikuya from the different courtesans.

Art usually plays a large amount in persuading me to purchase an otome game and this game has really pretty art in the character sprites (though it is a shame that they have removed the emofuri animations found in the original version of the game), CGS (especially Hanabusa's ones--being the newest) and trading cards. But to be honest, what else can you expect from a big otome game company.

There were a handful of times I have smiled/chuckled whilst playing the game especially during banter between the courtesans but they can't hold anything against some of the 'iffy' translations in the game.....e.g referring to a male's p**is as a 'wedge' xD

Unfortunately i'm currently grinding through Hayabusa's route - 'unfortunate' mostly due to personal preferences against the childhood friend route in otome games^^; However, overall I quite enjoy this game though I do wish that there was a 'skip read' option just to make replaying routes to get the alternate ending easier (though to be honest, it would only affect the last chapter) and an 'Autoplay' option like most otome games but once more, these are mostly due to personal preference.

I hope they'll introduce more characters (such as Kenji Ito currently not on this version) as well as sequels. The former probably having little chance of happening with the upcoming release of The Men of the Yoshiwara: Ohgiya (fingers crossed it'll be released on Steam! ^-^)

I played all routes and I can abolutely recommend this game, if you are into otome games then you have to give it a try. Most of the characters are interesting and the CGs are very beautiful. If you do buy this game then you should have  a fan at hand because some very steamy situations are coming your way.\n\nDon't forget that if we want more otome games on steam then we have to support the ones we already have!
